titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alfred Hulse Brooks Photographs and Papers
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:23

did.unittitle: Alfred Hulse Brooks photographs and papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Photographs and papers created and collected by Alfred Hulse Brooks and then probably maintained by Philip Sidney Smith, his successor as Geologist in Charge of the Division of Alaskan Mineral Resources of the United States Geological Survey. The collection provides visual documentation of the work of the United States Geological Survey in Alaska. Most of the photographs were made by Brooks and other employees of the agency. Some images document joint surveys made with the Geological Survey of Canada. The photographs depict mining operations, water and rail transportation, frontier communities, and Native American villages. Locations in Alaska well represented in the collection include Fairbanks, Juneau, Kennecott, Ketchikan, Skagway, Valdez, and Wrangell, as well as sites along the rivers, including the Copper River, Susitna River, and Tanana River. Numerous images throughout the collection also document sites in Canada, particularly in British Columbia. Photographs not created by the United States Geological Survey or its employees consist chiefly of images created by commercial photographers, corporate bodies, and government agencies in Alaska, collected principally by Brooks to supplement those created by him and his subordinates. Significant components include photographs related to the Cook Inlet Exploration Expedition under the command of Captain Edwin Forbes Glenn (1857-1926) in south-central Alaska in 1898; trips made by Robert Steed Dunn (1877-1955) in Alaska, 1900-1908; and the first successful ascent of the eastern peak of Mount Blackburn (later called Mount Kennedy) made by Dora Keen in May 1912.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Vintage Photographs on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2009.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Alfred Hulse Brooks Photographs and Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Alfred Hulse Brooks Photographs and Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Upon acquisition, the Alfred Hulse Brooks Photographs and Papers had no discernible order. Many attributions for images in the collection derive from the material itself and from comparison with digital surrogates available at the United States Geological Survey Central Regional Library, Denver, Colorado.

bioghist.head: Alfred Hulse Brooks (1871-1924)
bioghist.p: Alfred Hulse Brooks, an American geologist, was born in Ann Arbor, Michigan. He was the son of Martha G. Brooks (born 1850) and Thomas Benton Brooks (1836-1900), a mining engineer and geologist. Brooks received his elementary and secondary education in Newburgh, New York. He studied engineering in the Polytechnik Instituts of Stuttgart (1889) and of Munich (1890), and graduated from Harvard University in 1894.

During his studies, Brooks worked as a junior member of topographical mapping parties of the United States Geological Survey in Vermont (1888) and northern Michigan (1889), and in a geological party investigating potential iron ore lands in northern Michigan (1891). Upon graduation from Harvard, he gained an appointment with the United States Geological Survey and engaged in topographic and geological work in the Appalachian Mountains and Michigan. In August 1897, he attended the VIIth International Geological Congress in Saint Petersburg, Russia, and studied for several months in Paris, France, at the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle and Collège de France.

In March 1898, Brooks began working for the United States Geological Survey in Alaska. Between 1899 and 1911, he participated in six major expeditions that traversed Alaska to map its topography and geology. From 1903 until his death, he was Geologist in Charge of the Division of Alaskan Mineral Resources of the United States Geological Survey.

Brooks was a vice-chairman of the Alaska Railroad Commission (1911-1912), as well as president of the Geological Society of Washington (1911) and of the Washington Academy of Sciences (1921). In 1913, in recognition of his contributions in exploring and mapping Alaska, he received the Charles P. Daly Medal of the American Geographical Society and the Conrad Malte-Brun Medal of the Société de Géographie (Paris). In 1917-1919, he served as chief geologist of the American Expeditionary Force in France.
In 1903, Brooks married Mabel Whitman Baker Brooks (1876-1962). They had a daughter and son, Mary (born 1906) and Thomas Benton (born 1910).

bioghist.head: Philip Sidney Smith (1871-1924)
bioghist.p: Philip Sidney Smith (1877-1949) was born in Medford, Massachusetts. He earned three degrees in geology from Harvard (A. B., 1899; A.M., 1900, and Ph.D., 1904, where he taught geology from 1903 to 1906. In 1906, he began work with the United States Geological Survey in Alaska. In 1915, he became the Administrative Geologist of the Geological Survey and was later Acting Director. In 1925, he became Geologist in Charge of the Division of Alaskan Mineral Resources of the United States Geological Survey. Smith retired from government service in 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs and papers created and collected by Alfred Hulse Brooks and then probably maintained by Philip Sidney Smith, his successor as Geologist in Charge of the Division of Alaskan Mineral Resources of the United States Geological Survey. The collection provides visual documentation of the work of the United States Geological Survey in Alaska. Most of the photographs were made by Brooks and other employees of the agency. Some images document joint surveys made with the Geological Survey of Canada. The photographs depict mining operations, water and rail transportation, frontier communities, and Native American villages. Locations in Alaska well represented in the collection include Fairbanks, Juneau, Kennecott, Ketchikan, Skagway, Valdez, and Wrangell, as well as sites along the rivers, including the Copper River, Susitna River, and Tanana River. Numerous images throughout the collection also document sites in Canada, particularly in British Columbia. Photographs not created by the United States Geological Survey or its employees consist chiefly of images created by commercial photographers, corporate bodies, and government agencies in Alaska, collected principally by Brooks to supplement those created by him and his subordinates. Significant components include photographs related to the Cook Inlet Exploration Expedition under the command of Captain Edwin Forbes Glenn (1857-1926) in south-central Alaska in 1898; trips made by Robert Steed Dunn (1877-1955) in Alaska, 1900-1908; and the first successful ascent of the eastern peak of Mount Blackburn (later called Mount Kennedy) made by Dora Keen in May 1912.
Most images depict locations in Alaska, except where noted. Each folder in the collection usually contains a single photographic print.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: Series I. Photographs and Other Work by Employees of the United States Geological Survey, 1898-1955. Series II. Photographs by Other Photographers, 1892-1936.

did.unittitle: Photographs and Other Work by Employees of the United States Geological Survey

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Photographs Prepared for Publication and Other Work; Photographs by Identified Photographers; Photographs by Unidentified Photographers; and Photographic Negatives and Transparencies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographs created by or attributed to employees of the United States Geological Survey in Alaska that document the natural and built landscape in Alaska, as well as extractive industries, such as mining and fisheries.

did.unittitle: Photographs Prepared for Publication and Other Work

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists chiefly of photographs prepared to illustrate works published by the United States Geological Survey. Consists of photographic prints mounted on board or in folders. Most prints have annotations related to their reproduction. Also includes examples of maps created for publication by Brooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized chronologically by publication or planned publication.

did.unittitle: Eldridge, George Homans. A Reconnaissance in the Sushitna [sic] Basin and Adjacent Territory, Alaska, in 1898

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Formed part of United States Geological Survey, "Explorations in Alaska in 1898," Twentieth Annual Report, Part VII. (1900).
Images include Mount McKinley, Mount Susitna, Susitna River Valley, and Indian Creek.

did.unittitle: Purington, Chester Wells. List of possible illustrations for Methods and Costs of Gravel and Placer Mining in Alaska
Wright, Frederick Eugene, attributed. Typewritten labels for mineral samples collected from Prince of Wales Island and the Unuk River, British Columbia

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frederick Eugene Wright (1877-1953) was an American optician and geophysicist.

did.unittitle: Collier, Arthur J., Frank Lee Hess, Philip Sidney Smith, and Alfred Hulse Brooks. The Gold Placers of Parts of Seward Peninsula, Alaska, Including the Nome, Council, Kougarok, Port Clarence, and Goodhope Precincts (Bulletin No. 328)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph by Albert Barnes Kinne of Chauik Mountain from across Ophir Creek in 1903.

did.unittitle: Covert, Clermont Calvert, and Clarence Eugene Ellsworth. Water Supply Investigations in the Yukon-Tanana Region, Alaska, 1907 and 1908, Fairbanks, Circle, and Rampart Districts (Water Supply Paper No. 228)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include hydraulic mining on Eagle Creek, Hoosier Creek, and Little Minook Creek, and Thanksgiving Creek.

did.unittitle: Porter, Elmer A., Placer Mining in the Fortymile and Seventymile River Districts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Formed part of Alfred Hulse Brooks et al., Mineral Resources of Alaska: Report on Progress of Investigations in 1911 (Bulletin No. 520)
Images include hydraulic mining on Jack Wade Creek, the Mosquito Fork of the Fortymile River, and Crooked Creek.

did.unittitle: Henshaw, Fred Forbes, Glenn Lane Parker, Philip Sidney Smith, and Alfred Hulse Brooks. Surface Water Supply of Seward Peninsula, Alaska (Water Supply Paper No. 314)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include men using a large sluice box, also known as a "long tom," near Nome, and views of mining operations on Glacier Creek and Ophir Creek.

did.unittitle: Prindle, Louis Marcus, Philip S. Smith, and Frank James Katz. A Geologic Reconnaissance of the Fairbanks Quadrangle, Alaska (Bulletin No. 525)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Line drawing illustration of a head frame for a bucket hoist.

did.unittitle: Ellsworth, Clarence Eugene, and Royal William Davenport. Surface Water Supply of the Yukon-Tanana Region, Alaska (Water Supply Paper No. 342)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include Fortymile River, Little Minook Creek, Mastodon Creek, Quail Creek, Seventymile River, Troublesome Creek, and Wolverine Mountain.

did.unittitle: Ellsworth, Clarence Eugene, and Royal William Davenport. A Water-Power Reconnaissance in South-Central Alaska (Water Supply Paper No. 372)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of Port Valdez, looking north.

did.unittitle: Bagley, James Warren. Photographs that accompanied a presumably unpublished manuscript about diorite deposits in the vicinity of Sheep Creek and Kashwitna River
Brooks, Alfred Hulse. Maps of Alaska

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Distribution maps include navigable waters and railroads; copper deposits and producing areas; coal and petroleum; gold bearing areas and producing districts; vegetation; and arable land. Other maps outline physiographic provinces and mean annual temperatures and precipitation.

did.unittitle: Smith, Philip Sidney, and Gerald Arthur FitzGerald. Geologic Reconnaissance Map of Northwestern Alaska
Waring, Gerald A. Geology of the Anthracite Ridge Coal District, Alaska (Bulletin No. 861)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include Anthracite Ridge, Chugach Mountains, Chikootna Creek, Purinton Creek, Kutzkatna Creek, Muddy Creek, and of a diamond core drill in operation.

did.unittitle: List of illustrations to accompany a manuscript, probably by Gerald Arthur FitzGerald, Some Misconceptions Concerning Alaska for the Military Engineer
Photographs that accompanied a report about the Whalen Mine
Correspondence between Harvey Charles Orton of Chicago, Illinois, and Philip Sidney Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters about photographs that illustrate petroleum drilling operations in Controller Bay and near the Nichawak River.

did.unittitle: Cady, Wallace Martin, et al. The Central Kuskokwim Region, Alaska; An Account of its Geography, Geology, Geomorphology, and Mineral Resources (Professional Paper No. 268)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of the Kuskokwim River and Barometer Mountain made in June-August 1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs created by employees of the United States Geological Survey in Alaska. The majority of photographs are probably contact prints from negatives, as well as a small quantity of enlarged photographic prints or mounted contact prints. Photographs by James Madison Hill are accompanied by their corresponding original negatives. Some of the mounted prints were likely prepared for publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized by photographer and therein by the numbering schemes the employees applied to them, followed by larger photographic prints or mounted prints with the same organization. They are followed by photographs by unidentified creators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Bluff, Chilkoot Trail, Chilkoot Pass, Chisana River, Copper River, Douglas Island, Eagle, Gastineau Channel, Holy Cross, Juneau, Ketchikan, Nome, Skagway, Skwentna, St. Michael, Susitna River, Sweetcake Creek, Tanana River, Tortella (which became Nenana), Treadwell Mine, Tyonek, White River, and Wrangell. Images also includes informal portraits of Brooks and other topographers, including William John Peters (1863-1942), as well as survey and mining camps; moose and caribou trophies; steamboats; and Native American communities, including totem poles and houses.
A group of images also documents a trip by Brooks to Ireland, Scotland, and Switzerland in June-July 1906.

did.unittitle: Trip to Ireland, Scotland, and Switzerland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views from the steamship Oceanic of the coast of Ireland; sites in Scotland, including the Caledonian Canal, a bridge at Inverness, Abbotsford House, and Melrose Abbey, as well as Lochs Katrine and Lomand; and views of the Bernese Alps, Switzerland, including a glacier on Eiger, as well as views of Grindelwald and Bern.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of mining operations in the vicinity of Kuskokwim River, including Barometer Mine and Red Devil Mine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views include hydraulic mining in the Yentna Cache-Creek Mining District and a pack train crossing the Russell Glacier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of along the Copper River and Northwestern Railway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of hydraulic mining.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of mining operations, probably in the vicnity of Manley Hot Springs, as well as steam boats and canoes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a view of Juneau from Mount Logan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of the Copper River and Northwestern Railway, the Alaska Railroad, and the Treadwell Mine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a views of Yakutat and the Gastineau Channel, and an image of the mail steamer Dora.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a view of the dock and ore bunkers of the Beatson-Bonanza Mine on La Touche Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of Faith Creek and from Mount Okumiak.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images includes steamboats, including the stern wheel steamboat Sarah.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes images of hydraulic mining and views of the Ellamar Copper Mine and an informal portrait of Alfred Hulse Brooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views consisting Tanalian Falls and a sailboat on Iliamna Lake.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an informal portrait of a Native American family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of a mining operation from a distance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of Native Americans created during the Anglo-American Polar Expedition at Barrow, including a meal of Snow Goose eggs and skinning Dall Sheep.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of a freight scow on the Upper Koyukuk River and of the Nolan Creek Valley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of waterfronts, a steamboat, and pack train.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of mining operations and exploration in the vicinity of the Dall River; views of Lake Laberge and Dawson City in the Yukon, Canada; and the mail steamer Dora at Hunter Bay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of a man with a pack train of horses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of men and packhorses along the Kenai River and of the Kennecott Mines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of mining operations in and around Eagle, Nome, and Ophir, as well as views of Skagway and of the White Pass Hotel Station. Also includes an informal portrait of a Native American with a spear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of mining operations in the vicinity of Fairbanks, including Goldstream Creek and Mastoon Creek, as well as views of Quail Creek and Fortymile Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of mining operations on Pedro Creek and Ophir Creek and used to illustrate an article in Mining Magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View from a distance of a mine on a waterfront.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of an Eskimo Umiak in the Bering Sea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views including the McPherson Fox Ranch on Naked Island, a mesa in the vicnity of the Koyukuk River and sluicing on Myrtle Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views include steamboats among ice floes in the Bering Sea; an aerial view of a dredger; and mining operations at Willow Creek and Ophir Creek. Other images includes a man dismembering a whale at the Akutan whaling station and a group of gold nuggets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dogs hauling a boat partly loaded over tundra in the Etivluk-Aniuk Pass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of views of ships, including freight steamboat Santa Clara and towing tugs Perry and Uncle Sam at Kayak

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of a rock outcrop at the Stampede antimony mine at Stampede Creek

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the sternwheeler steamboat Wallace Langley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of a view east from Mount Brown and a view of the United States Revenue Cutter Rush.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes images related to joint surveying expeditions by the United States Geological Survey and Geological Survey of Canada of Alaska and the British Northwest Territories at Marsh Lake, Yukon. Other images in Canada include Miles Canyon and the Yukon River, Yukon, and Bennett, British Columbia, as well as Chilkat Pass, between British Columbia and Alaska. Images in Alaska include views of the Bluff, Kelhini River, Pyramid Harbor, and Wrangell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of Iron Creek into the valley of a north flowing tributary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images document several mining operations including Crites and Feldmann Mine, Elms Gold Mining Company, Eva Creek Mining Company, Fairbanks Exploration Company, Road Metal Quarry, Saint Paul Mill, and Zimmerman Hydraulic Mine. Locations of operations include Bedrock Creek, Chatnika River, Cleary Creek, Eva Creek, Ferry, Goldstream, Happy Creek, Moose Pup (a tributary of Fairbanks Creek), Saint Patrick Creek, Sourdough Creek, Twin Creek, and Wolf Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of hydraulic mining on Eagle Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the Cassiterite Lode and surrounding country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of open cut mining on beach of Glacier Creek and an example of a derrick bucket.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of a contorted schist near Mosquito Fork with an accompanying description by Prindle, and views of mining operations, including a steam shovel Mammoth Creek and sluices on Mastodon Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the waterfront and beach of Nome.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of hydraulic mining on Daniels Creek.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized by location, including the lines of two Alaskan railroads, followed by subjects, then portraits of identified individuals and group portraits, and then the same organization applied to enlargements and mounted photographic prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of processing a fin whale and removing its blubber

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of an Iñupiat celebration and children playing

did.unittitle: Broad Pass and a surveyor using a plane table
Council City and Solomon River Railroad

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of the Burns Slough bridge on the Seward-Kenai Road and Snow River, as well as a portrait of guide Charles Emswiler with a large bear trophy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include views of the Ruby Creek Copper Mine, and the mining operations on Dahl Creek of Louis Lloyd, Ase D. Wilcox, Frank Knight, and Thomas Shea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of an Iñupiat celebration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes views of canoes and other ships, such as the sloop Gjøa, and several steamboats, including Beilby, Casca, Novelty, Queen, Senator, and Tyrrell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of mining operations include a dredger for the De Soto Placer Mining Company and a man at the opening of the Grotto Mine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of a railroad and draisines among snow drifts, as well as an automobile on Richardson Highway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of views of a salmon trap and a caribou herd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Portraits include a man with a mammoth tusk and a Native American man with a large Chinook salmon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes portraits of parties that accompanied Walter Lowrie Fisher, Secretary of the Interior, during his tour of Alaska in the summer of 1911, which include Alfred Hulse Brooks and Alaskan Governor Walter Eli Clark. Other identified individuals in group portraits include Frederick W. Hollender, Alexander Duncan McRae, Sidney Paige, and Philip Sidney Smith.

did.unittitle: Atlin and McKee Creek, British Columbia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of a dragline excavator operated by the United States Smelting, Mining and Refining Company.

Hurricane Gulch and the Hurricane Bridge
Kanalku Bay and the McCluskey Mine
Kennicott and the Kennecott Copper Mine
Kuskulana River and the North Midas Copper Company
Lurvey Basin (also known as Silver Bow Basin)
Seward and the United States Revenue Cutter Tahoma
Saint Paul Island and a seal rookery
Tanana River, Tanana River Bridge, and steamboat Martha Clow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Group portrait consisting of Alfred Hulse Brooks, Leonard M. Cox, Colin M. Ingersoll, and Jay Johnson Morrow.

did.unittitle: Copy photograph of an outline, "Alaska Mineral Resources: Principal Factors Controlling their Development"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of donkeys and horses of a pack train.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Aerial view of a lumberyard for a railway.

did.unittitle: Copy photographs on glass negatives, 5 x 7 inches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a boy dressed in fur and holding harpoon; men hunting for seals among ice floes near Nome; an aerial view of a camp on a beach, and portraits of a man and a woman.
Several of the original images were originally created by Lomen Brothers, Nome.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cabin of miner and prospector Sam Means (born 1860) on May Creek near Chititu, probably created by Means.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into three subseries: Photographs by Identified Photographers, Photographs by Identified Photographers, and Panoramas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs created by photographers and corporate bodies of sites and subjects chiefly in Alaska.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized alphabetically by the photographer or corporate body, followed by unidentified photographers, then by a small group of panoramas by Albert Barnes Kinne and McRae Brothers Limited

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include views of railway tunnels and a rotary snow plow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of the images were created by Henry G. Kaiser. Images of the Alaska Railroad include construction of the railway toward Turnagain, a trestle at Tunnel No. 1, and a railroad bridge over Tanana River. Images of boats include the Alaska Engineering Commission boat Betty M. on Susitna River and the Steamship Admiral Watson unloading freight at Knik. Other images include coal mines at Eska and gold mining operations in Chatanika.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of views of Fairweather Mountain, Mount Crillon, and the LaPerouse Glacier.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Guy Francis Cameron (born 1874) was a photographer and tailor in Valdez.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the Sheep Creek bridge on the Richardson Highway.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Century Syndicate was a publicity bureau established by the by the National Association of Manufacturers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images chiefly of the Copper River and the surrounding region from the steamer Chitina and includes the Abercrombie Rapids, Allen Glacier, Baird Canyon, Mount Blackburn, Bremner River, Regal Mountain, Taral, and Wood Canyon. Other images include views of the Kennecott Copper Mine and a construction camp established by Michael J. Heney (1864-1910), a contractor for the Copper River and Northwestern Railway. Also includes an informal portrait Stephen Birch (1872-1940) a mining engineer and founder of Kennecott Copper. Accompanied by a list of captions.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Wight Chapman (1858-1939) was an Episcopalian missionary in Anvik from 1887 to 1930.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Portrait of Ralph Wood of Anvik, an Ingalik berdache and specialist in fine bead and fur work.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: August William Conradt (1878-1967) was a miner and insurance agent in Fairbanks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include Carl Tweiten and George Tweiten at the a gold claim in the vicinity of Ptarmigan Creek and views of Mount Hayes and Mount Hess.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Cook Inlet Exploration Expedition under the command of Captain Edwin Forbes Glenn (1857-1926) in south-central Alaska explored the country north of Cook Inlet to discover the most "direct and practicable" route from the coast to the Tanana River.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include a group portrait of the expedition, interior and exterior views of the salmon cannery for the Pacific Steam Whaling Company at Prince William Sound; views of the steamer Salmo, and a group portrait of Native American men and others in a ship. Identified individuals include Lieutenant Joseph C. Castner, Walter Curran Mendenhall, Private George W. Van Schoonhoven, Private Adelbert L. Canwell, and guide Harry H. Hicks.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Edward Sheriff Curtis (1868-1952) was a photographer known for his images of the American West and of Native Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of a glacier and a river created during the Harriman Alaska Expedition a maritime expedition sponsored by Edward Harriman to explore and document the Alaskan coast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of a rock strata on the bank of the Chickaloon River.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Beverly Bennett Dobbs (1868-1937) was a photographer in Bellingham, Washington, from 1888 until 1900, when he moved to Nome and continued his photography work. By 1903, he formed a partnership with the San Francisco photographer Albert Barnes Kinne (1853-1925). Around 1909, he established the Alaska Moving Picture Co. By 1911, Dobbs sold his photography negatives to the Lomen Brothers. Around 1914, he moved to Seattle and managed the Dobbs Totem Film Company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of the disparate mining operations of the Miocene Ditch Company, Three Friends Mining Company, and Topkok Ditch Company at Bluff and on the Solomon River.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Robert Steed Dunn (1877-1955) graduated from Harvard in 1898 and was an explorer, author, naval officer, and journalist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs that document trips Dunn made with R. W. "Jack" Gray, probably Ralph Weld Gray (1880-1944), in the Wrangell Volcanic Field, July-August 1900, and Peters Glacier and Mount McKinley, July-September 1903, as well as views of the summit of Mount Wrangell made during an ascent he made with William Soule in 1908. Accompanied by a map created by Dunn and Gray of the Wrangell Volcanic Field, 1900.

Some images illustrated articles Dunn published in Outing, an Illustrated Monthly Magazine of Recreation . These include "Finding a Volcano and Wiping a 16,000 feet Mountain from the Map of Alaska" (December 1902), "Into the Mists of Mt. McKinley" (February 1904), "Stormwrapped on Mt. McKinley" (March 1904), "Highest on Mt. McKinley" (April 1904), and "Home by Ice and By Swimming" (May 1904). Some images also illustrated his article, "Conquering Our Greatest Volcano: The First Ascent of Mount Wrangell, Alaska" in Harper's Magazine (March 1909).

did.unittitle: Map of the Wrangell Volcanic Field

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Joseph Henry Eglar (circa 1870-1933) was a fisherman in Tacoma, Washington, and a miner in Alaska and the Yukon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of a gold and tin mining operation in Tofty.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Harry Clifford Fassett (1870-1953) was joined the crew of the United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross in 1889 and kept its records until 1910. From 1911 to 1919, he represented the United States Bureau of Fisheries in Alaska.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of views of Yakutat Bay and chiefly of the Hubbard Glacier.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Charles William Felch was a photographer in Nome.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of a pack train with supplies crossing Otter Creek at Flat and a mining operation at Otter Creek.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Eric A. Hegg (1867-1947) was a photographer active in Nome, Cordova, and the Yukon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist chiefly of sites along the Copper River and Northwestern Railway including the Flag Point Bridge, the Miles Glacier Bridge, and the Steel Bridge over the Kuskulana River. Other images include emigrants at Chilkoot Pass in 1898 and a view of Chitina, as well as a group portrait of the Alaska Railway Commission, consisting of Colin M. Ingersoll, Alfred Hulse Brooks, Leonard M. Cox, and Jay Johnson Morrow.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Orville George Herning (1868-circa 1947) represented the Klondike and Boston Mining Company in Knik from 1898-1905, and operated the Knik Trading Company from 1905-1917. He oversaw construction of the Klondike and Boston Trail from Knik to the Willow Creek Mining District (The Herning Trail). From 1917, he operated a general store in Wasilla.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include men, horses, and wagons on a road as government surveyors arrive in Knik.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Alfred Cyril Hirschfeld (1866-1926) was a photographer in Atlin, British Columbia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of mining operations in British Columbia including the Atlin Mining Company on McKee Creek; the Société minière de la Colombie Britannique and the De Lamare Hydraulic Syndicate on Boulder Creek; and the Atlin Lake Mining Company in Atlin. There is also a view of the community of Discovery.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1893, Grace Porter Hopkins (born 1873) married Randolph D. Hopkins (born 1857), and they both worked in the United States Labor Department in Washington, D. C. She regularly contributed articles to newspapers and magazines, and authored The Economy Administration Cook Book (1913) with Susie Root Rhodes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs possibly created by Alfred Hulse Brooks and collected by Porter, that document United States Geological Survey expeditions in Alaska. Images include an informal portrait of William John Peters and Walter Curran Mendenhall on the Fish River

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Harriet Elizabeth Frost Hunt (1865-1934) was married to Forest Joseph Hunt (1858-1947), a mayor of Ketchikan and member of the Alaska Senate. She was the first Republican National Committee woman from Alaska and a founder of the Ketchikan Public Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the Copper Mount smelter, Coppermount, Prince of Wales Island.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Phinney S. Hunt (1866-1917) was a photographer in Valdez from 1898. In 1915, he became the official photographer for the Alaskan Engineering Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include trees at the Alaska Agricultural Experiment Station covered in ash from the eruption of Novarupta, a view of the Cliff Mine at Valdez Bay, A view of the Valdez-Fairbanks Trail outside lower end of Keystone Canyon, and a depiction of a man collecting ice worms from a glacier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of rock fill from by the Resurrection Bay Mining Company from the steamer dock at Seward.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Albert John Johnson (1874 or 1878-1926) emigrated to the United States from Denmark in 1886. He worked as a photographer in Fairbanks and Nenana, as well as Oakland, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcards distributed by Johnson and Hall's Bookstore, a book store owned by Frank B. Hall in Fairbanks. Images chiefly depict Fairbanks, including L. F. Protzman Groceries, Nordale Hotel, McIntosh and Kubon Prescription Druggists, and the Alaska Agricultural Experiment Station, as well as a Fourth of July celebration and a visit by Santa Claus to Hall's Book Store. Other images include the coalfields of T. R. McGuire on the Nenana River and mining operations on Cleary Creek. Accompanied by an album with an inscription from Hall to Brooks, October 13, 1912.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frank Harold Johnson (born 1894) was a businessman in Chicago with interests in Alaskan petroleum extraction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of petroleum drilling operations on the Nichawak River. Accompanied by correspondence between Harvey Charles Orton (1890-1961), a business engineer and consultant in Chicago, and Philip Sidney Smith about the images.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Albert John Johnson and probably Andrew V. Tyler (born circa 1894) were photographers who worked together. Tyler also worked as a photographer with the United States Signal Corps in Valdez.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the Healy River Coal Corporation mine at Healy.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Henry G. Kaiser (born 1866) was a photographer in Nome, Anchorage, and Fairbanks, and an official photographer for the Alaska Engineering Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy photographs that consist of a view of a caribou herd at Sinook and a mining dredge.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Kaufmann & Fabry Co. is commercial photography firm founded in 1903 by Charles Kaufmann and Herman Fabry in Chicago, Illinois.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of the Alaska exhibit at the American Mining Congress annual meeting in Chicago, Illinois.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Dora Keen (1871-1963) was an American traveler and mountain climber, as well as a social social reformer and educator. She married George William Handy (1881-1982) on July 8, 1916; they divorced in 1932.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images document the first successful ascent of the eastern peak of Mount Blackburn (later called Mount Kennedy) in the Wrangell Mountains by Dora Keen and George W. Handy via the Kennicott Glacier in May 1912. Each image includes inscriptions in the negatives that describe the landscape and views.

The photographs are accompanied by a two letters to Brooks from Keen, December 13, 1912, and January 31, 1913. They describe her ascent and request his assistance in identifying a mountain near Mount Blackburn.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frank La Roche (1853-1936) was a photographer in Seattle, Washington. He made trips to southeastern Alaska and the Yukon Territory, especially during the Klondike gold rush.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include views of Skagway, the Chilkoot Summit from Crater Lake, and the Klondike River.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Merl LaVoy (1886-1953) was a photographer, documentary film maker, and cameraman for Pathé News.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of two men from the expedition of Herschel Parker and Belmore Browne en route up northeast ridge of Mount McKinley and men operating an electric drill at Copper Mountain (later called Mount Eielson), as well as views of Cape Saint Elias and miners near the Kuskulana River.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: William Ernest Logemann (1885-1952) was a photographer in Anchorage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the coal cleaning plant and tipple of the Evan Jones Mine at Jonesville.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lomen Reindeer Corporation was a company headed by brothers, Carl Joys Lomen (1880-1965) and Alfred Julian Lomen (1889-1950) to market reindeer meat, 1914-1939. The Lomen brothers also operated a photographic firm that purchased studios and glass negatives of earlier Nome photographers, including Beverly Bennett Dobbs, and Frank H. Nowell; the building for this firm burned in 1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of hybrid reindeer and caribou herds at Egavik.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Edward H. Mack (1864-1935) was a clerk in the United States District Court in Fairbanks, as well as an insurance and real estate agent, and a Secretary and treasurers of the Fairbanks Commercial Club

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of buildings at Chena Hot Springs.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Maximillian "Max" Manger (born 1874) was a commercial photographer in Fairbanks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informal portrait of Alfred Hulse Brooks and John Hallowell, Assistant Secretary of the Department of the Interior, in a Ford automobile and an image of a crowd of men on a sidewalk in front of the Nordale Hotel in Fairbanks.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: McRae Brothers Limited was bookseller and stationery firm in Prince Rupert, British Columbia owned by Duncan C. McRae.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of the Zanardi River Bridge in Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Sam Means (born 1860) was a prospector and amateur photographer in Kennicott and May Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images that depict the Kennecott Copper Mine at Kennicott, including the Jumble Mine.

did.unittitle: Miller, N. B. and Charles Haskins Townsend

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: N. B. Miller (died 1897) was an assistant naturalist aboard the USS Albatross, a vessel manned by the United States Navy and assigned to the United States Fish Commission. Miller served aboard the USS Albatross for fourteen years preceding his death from

Charles Haskins Townsend (1859-1944) was an American zoologist. From 1897 to 1902 he served as the chief of the fisheries division of the United States Fish Commission. From 1902 to 1937, he served as director of the New York Aquarium at Castle Garden.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views created by the partnership of Miller and Townsend of a glacier, probably the Hubbard Glacier in Yakutat Bay, from the USS Albatross.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Edward C. Morse (born 1872) was a journalist and mine superintendent at the Sea Level Mine on Revillagigedo Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image depicts the Sea Level Mine during its construction on Revillagigedo Island.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frank H. Nowell (1864-1950) was a photographer in Nome, Alaska, and Seattle, Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images near Nome include the operations Center Creek Mining Company, the Gertrude Mine, the Wild Goose Company. Several images show dredges of the Three Friends Mining Company in the Solomon River, as well as Dredge No.1 (Wisconsin) of Bursik and Co. in the Snake River.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Louis H. Pedersen (born 1867) was a clergyman for churches in Douglas, 1901-1905; Seward, 1905-1913; and Skagway, 1913. He also made postcard photographs during the early twentieth century. His sons Frederick Louis Pedersen (born 1893) and Ralph Martin Pedersen (born 1894) operated the Pedersen Brothers studio in Skagway, which sold photographic postcards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images consist of a view of USS Maryland in Resurrection Bay; and a montage of five photos advertising economic opportunities in Knik sponsored by the Knik Commercial Club.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Party that accompanied Walter Lowrie Fisher, Secretary of the Interior, during his tour of Alaska, which includes Alfred Hulse Brooks and Alaskan Governor Walter Eli Clark

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Herman Werner Reeth (born 1864) was an author, inventor, and miner in Bethel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images near Bethel and on the Kisaralik River, which include views of the Golden Gate Falls and hydraulic mining.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Harry Fielding Reid (1859-1944) was a geologist known for his contributions in the fields of seismology and glaciology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Charpentier Glacier and the Hugh Miller Inlet.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: William Schneider was a partner in Schneider Bros., a mining operation on Little Creek, a tributary to the Innoko River.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images depict hydraulic mining.

did.unittitle: Shade, Orie Irving, or Charles A. Shade

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Orie Irving Shade (1877-1963) and Charles A. Shade (born 1887) were brothers living in Tanana, circa 1915-1920. The former managed a general store in Tanana in 1930, and the latter served in World War I and later worked as a postal carrier in Nenena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Time lapse photograph of Sun taken at intervals of twenty minutes during a Winter Solstice in Tanana.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Hudson Stuck (1863-1920) was an archdeacon with the Protestant Episcopal Church in Fort Yukon. Stuck and Harry P. Karstens led the first expedition that successfully climbed the South Summit of Mount McKinley in June 1913.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include a group portrait of Native Americans at Lake Minchumina, a dog sled en route between Cos Jacket and Lake Minchumina, and landscape views.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Edward Thwaites (1863-1940) was an amateur photographer and a clerk for the Railway Mail Service. From 1905 to 1912, he lived on the mailboat steamer Dora owned by the Northwestern Steamship Company and traveled the route from Valdez to Unalaska delivering mail to the coastal communities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include a United States Navy ship near the Taku Glacier in the Taku Inlet, views of Kodiak from the water, a cannery ship in Bristol Bay, and the steamer Dora.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Arch James Tourtellotte (1878-1959) was an accountant in Portland, Oregon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include mining operations of Klery Placers, Inc., on Klery Creek and mining operations on Squirrel Creek.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Calvin F. Townsend was a game warden with the United States Bureau of Fisheries and based in Fairbanks from 1913 to 1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of a gray fox at the Kayak Island Fox Ranch.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Edgar Phillip Tweet (born 1900) was a miner in Teller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of a rock outcrop at the Stampede antimony mine at Stampede Creek

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of two men aboard the agency boat, Ranger I, at a Sitka dock on Silver Bay.

did.unittitle: United States Navy Alaska Aerial Survey Expedition

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: United States Navy Alaska Aerial Survey Expedition took place in 1926 and 1929 to acquire vertical images for creating topographic maps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images include aerial views of Ketchikan, a glacier, and a forest.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Valentine & Sons was a printing company established in 1851 by James Valentine (1814-1879) in Dundee, Scotland. The firm was a pioneer in the postcard industry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcard views of the exhibits at the Museum of the Geological Survey of Canada in the Victoria Memorial Museum Building in Ottawa, Ontario.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Western Alaska Construction Company was established in Chicago, circa 1903. It was the lead contractor in building the Council City and Solomon River Railroad.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of the general offices of the company in Dickson and related to the construction of the Council City and Solomon River Railroad.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Winter & Pond was a photography studio of Lloyd Valentine Winter (1866-1945) and Edwin Percy Pond (1872-1943) in Juneau, 1893-1943.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of mining operations that include the Alaska Treadwell Gold Mining Company on Douglas Island; the Alaska Juneau Mine at Silver Bow Basin; the Eagle River Mining Company at Amalga; the Ebner Gold Mining Company in Juneau; the Ebner Gold Mines Company and Humboldt Mining Company at Gold Creek; the Mellen Mining Company and the Kensington Mining Company at Berners Bay; and the Porcupine Mining Company at Porcupine River. A view hydraulic mining in the Silver Bow Basin includes Edwin Percy Pond with a camera.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frank Eddy Wolfe (born 1869) was born in Ohio and operated a photograph studio in Dawson City, Yukon. In 1924, he lived in Los Angeles, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of mining operations in the Yukon, including Bonanza Creek, Dominion Creek, Eldorado Creek, and Hunker Creek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mill in the foreground and tent city in the distance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Man with a portable testing mill at the Jumbo Claim on the west side of Klag Bay.

did.unittitle: Georgetown, Ohio, and three men at Buttermilk Falls
Ketchikan and the steamship City of Seattle in dry dock.
Kodiak Island, and the steamship Admiral Sampson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the waterfront and of the motorship Kennecott.

did.unittitle: Prince William Sound and Shoup Glacier

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Group around an open railcar and a display of eight bear skins.

did.unittitle: Skeena River, British Columbia, and the steamship Inlander
Child wearing a parka and pulling a sled

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Albert Barnes Kinne (1853-1925) operated photography studios in San Francisco, Nome, and Council. He was also a partner with Beverly B. Dobbs in their Nome studio, Dobbs & Kinne, 1903-1905.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Panoramic view of a freight scow with sail on the Neukluk River.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images in the vicinity of British Columbia include a view from Mount Oldfield of Digby Island and a view of the Zanardi River Bridge.

did.unittitle: Panoramas of a bay and valley
Men and supplies on a river barge pulled by a horse
Ridgeline of a mountain range and a man posed prone on the ridge of a mountain
